metadata.title: Vascular surgery in the COVID-19 pandemic

body_text.text: A novel outbreak named coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) continues to challenge the healthcare system globally. By the beginning of April, more than 1,000,000 positive cases with 51,737 deaths have been reported (1). A worldwide response to maintain the healthcare system is essential during the pandemic. The main reason for delaying the elective procedures is to ensure that the healthcare system keeps up with the pandemic. Numerous concerns emerge regarding whether to defer the vascular procedures as well as the protection measures in the course of treatment of a COVID-19 patient.

In Turkey, the Ministry of Health and the hospital administrators have taken certain precautions to handle this situation at the outbreak of this pandemic. Deferring the elective operations and redefining the major hospitals as “pandemic hospitals” are the main measures taken by authorities. The majority of the larger volume cardiovascular centers have become pandemic hospitals mainly serving COVID-19 patients. Even though some hospitals have at first seemed like they would be COVID-free; later on, the impossibility of having any COVID-free center during this rapidly increasing pandemic has been realized. In this context; our center, which is also a designated pandemic hospital, has deferred all elective operations, to the greatest extent possible. The arrangements of shifts for the workplaces have been organized such as to have a vascular surgeon on duty at all times (one day on and four days off for each surgeon) especially for all types of open vascular surgeries. Moreover, our endovascular surgical team consisting of two senior and four junior surgeons is at all times on call for endovascular procedures.

Availability of the surgical and anesthesia staff, accessibility of the operating room (OR) and angio-suit, and readiness of surgical equipment and supplies (such as grafts, sutures and blood products) are considered of top priority when taking decisions to whether to implement an operation on the patient. Beside the health-center capacity, the emergency situations should be determined specifically for each surgical specialty. Therefore, we have employed a concept of “Level of Priority” for cardiovascular procedures (2). The modified version of this concept for vascular surgery is summarized at Table I
. The classification of cases under the major headings may be relevant in terms of making decisions for patients during the pandemic. This is also essential for protecting the healthcare staff from possible/asymptomatic COVID patients. Patients whose COVID status is unknown can be better identified through this classification. LoP I conditions can be delayed to the greatest extent possible. LoP II-IV conditions should be reconsidered on each patient basis and the availability of the healthcare system. In our center, all LoP I patients are subjected to deferral, and our team is diligently dealing with all urgent and emergency cases. In the last decade, the tendency to implement endovascular procedures on many patients has prevailed in vascular surgery. The current situation may provide us with a chance to treat patients upon a decline in the durations of operations in open surgeries and the surgeries implemented with local/regional anesthesia which are preferred over intubation and the use of ventilators to minimize the potential for exposure to aerosol generating procedures (3). Endovascular procedures may be beneficial for blood conservation as well.

Healthcare providers have to take care of patients, putting themselves at a high risk of COVID-19. Personal protective equipment (PPE) is a key issue for healthcare workers. On the other hand, shortage of PPE has been reported in many centers. PPE for surgical team includes certain extra equipment compared to the standardized PPE. A face shield over goggles and mask, surgical coat and preferably double gloves fixed with adhesive drapes to the surgical coat are recommended for additional protection during surgery (2). Aside from PPE, the preparation of OR, transportation of the patient and disinfection measures for OR stand out as other important concerns (2).

In conclusion, the “Level of Priority” concept may be regarded as of value for deciding whether to defer a vascular surgical procedure. Indeed, any expert opinions and correspondences may offer a great value for addressing the issue of what to do for longer-term deferral of the cases. When performing a vascular surgery (endovascular or open) for a suspected / confirmed COVID-19 patient, full protection should be supplied for healthcare workers in the OR or angio-suit.
